After I learned to do some fun things in R, I noticed that I needed datasets to practice my new skills.
I know there are some already built in R (added a nice list here) but I also wanted to "choose" something that aligns more with what I do or may enjoy learning about, so here are other ones I found too.

**What is this?**

## [ARDA (Association of Religion Data Archives) Data Archive](https://www.thearda.com/data-archive/browse-categories)

Added Fri Apr 28th, 2023

**What is this?**

**Excerpt from site:** The ARDA Data Archive is a collection of surveys, polls, and other data submitted by researchers and made available online by the ARDA.\

\
There are 1,236 data files included in the ARDA collection.
You can browse files by category, [alphabetically](https://www.thearda.com/data-archive/browse-alphabetically), view the [newest additions](https://www.thearda.com/data-archive/browse-newest-additions), or search for a file.
Once you select a file you can preview the results, read about how the data were collected, review the survey questions asked, save selected survey questions to your own file, and/or download the data file.

1.  Link to datasets here: <https://www.thearda.com/data-archive/browse-categories>

## [crimedatasets: A Comprehensive Collection of Crime-Related Datasets](https://lightbluetitan.github.io/crimedatasets/) ðŸ’¯

By Renzo Caceres Rossi

Added Thu Feb 20, 2025

**What is this?**

The **crimedatasets** package offers a comprehensive collection of datasets focused on crimes, criminal activities, and related topics.
It serves as a valuable resource for researchers, analysts, and students interested in crime analysis, criminology, and socio-economic studies related to criminal behavior.
The package includes datasets spanning global and local contexts, available in various structures such as tibbles, data frames, tables, and spatial data (simple features).
Each dataset is named with a suffix indicating its structure, facilitating easy identification and usage.

1.  Link to package here: <https://lightbluetitan.github.io/crimedatasets/>

## [National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions-III (NESARC-III)](https://www.niaaa.nih.gov/research/nesarc-iii)

Added Fri Apr 28th, 2023

**What is this?**

**Excerpt from site:** The National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions-III (NESARC-III) was sponsored, designed and directed by the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA).
The NESARC-III is cross-sectional, based on a nationally representative sample of the civilian noninstitutionalized population of the United States aged 18 years and older.
Fieldwork was conducted by Westat through a contract under the data collection authorization of Title 42 USC 285n.
Utilizing the NIAAA Alcohol Use Disorder and Associated Disabilities Interview Schedule (AUDADIS-5), the NESARC-III collected information on alcohol and drug use and disorders, related risk factors, and associated physical and mental disabilities.
In addition, DNA was obtained through saliva samples.
The final sample size was 36,309 and included persons living in households and select noninstitutional group quarters.

1.  Link to dataset here: <https://www.niaaa.nih.gov/research/nesarc-iii>

## [National Couples' Health and Time Study (NCHAT)](https://pop.umn.edu/data/nchat)

Added Fri Apr 28th, 2023

**What is this?**

**Excerpt from site:** The National Couples' Health and Time Study (NCHAT) is a nationally-representative, multi-method study of cohabiting and married individuals ages 20 to 60 who were in a same- or different-gender couple in the United States during the COVID-19 pandemic.
The sample includes 3,642 main respondents and 1,515 spouses/partners.
The survey and time diary with experience sampling methods focus on relationship functioning, emotion regulation, discrimination, racial trauma, physical health, psychological well-being, health behaviors, stressors, and time use.

1.  Link to dataset here: <https://pop.umn.edu/data/nchat>

## [Project on Human Development in Chicago Neighborhoods (PHDCN)](https://www.icpsr.umich.edu/web/NACJD/series/206)

Added Fri Apr 28th, 2023

**What is this?**

**Excerpt from site:** The Project on Human Development in Chicago Neighborhoods (PHDCN) is a large-scale, interdisciplinary study of how families, schools, and neighborhoods affect child and adolescent development.
It was designed to advance the understanding of the developmental pathways of both positive and negative human social behaviors.
In particular, the project examined the causes and pathways of juvenile delinquency, adult crime, substance abuse, and violence.
At the same time, the project also provided a detailed look at the environments in which these social behaviors take place by collecting substantial amounts of data about urban Chicago, including its people, institutions, and resources.

1.  Link to list of datasets here: <https://www.icpsr.umich.edu/web/NACJD/series/206>
